script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi, I'm Dr. Martinez. What brings you in today?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: It's Emma, she's been wheezing since this morning and her inhaler isn't helping like it usually does. I'm really worried.

script.speaker: child
script.text: My chest feels tight mommy

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay Emma, let me listen to your chest. When did the wheezing start exactly?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Around 6 AM when she woke up. She was fine yesterday but then started this dry cough last night.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Has she had any fever? Any runny nose or congestion?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No fever that I noticed, but she did have some sniffles yesterday. Is she going to be okay?

script.speaker: child
script.text: It hurts to breathe

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I know sweetie, we're going to help you feel better. How many puffs of albuterol has she had today?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I gave her two puffs around 7 AM, then two more about an hour ago. Should I have given her more?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That's appropriate. Any known triggers? Pets, dust, recent illness in the family?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Her dad had a cold last week, and we did visit my sister who has cats on Sunday. Oh god, I should have thought of that.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Don't blame yourself. Emma, can you take a big deep breath for me like a balloon?

script.speaker: child
script.text: I can't, it's too hard

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I can hear wheezing bilaterally and some retractions. What's her usual asthma control like?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Usually pretty good. She uses her inhaler maybe once or twice a week, but this is the worst it's been in months.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Any allergies to medications?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: No, none that we know of.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay, I'm going to give her a breathing treatment with albuterol and we'll see how she responds.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Is it gonna taste yucky?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: It might taste a little funny, but it's going to help your breathing. You'll wear this mask like a superhero.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: How long will the treatment take? Should I be doing something different at home?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: About ten minutes. After this, if she improves, we'll likely send you home with a steroid to prevent this from happening again.

script.speaker: child
script.text: I don't want medicine

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Emma, you need to listen to the doctor. Will the steroid have side effects?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Short course, minimal side effects. She might be a little more energetic. Let's start the nebulizer treatment now.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay, thank you. I just feel so helpless when she can't breathe properly.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You did the right thing bringing her in. We'll monitor her response and go from there.

script.speaker: child
script.text: Mommy, stay with me

script.speaker: parent
script.text: I'm right here baby. How will I know if this happens again when to bring her in?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: If her rescue inhaler isn't providing relief after two treatments, or if she's struggling to speak or eat, come back immediately.
